A customer might place three separate orders in one day because different buyers control different budgets, or submit orders with arbitrary line splits that create extra touches. For perishable goods, it monitors expiration dates and spoilage risk. For durable goods, it flags style/model transitions and technology obsolescence windows. The system continuously calculates aging metrics — days on hand, turn rate by location, seasonal velocity patterns — and surfaces action-ready recommendations to merchandising and operations teams. ## Inventory Planning & Replenishment → Returns/Obsolescence/Shrinkage

AI-driven inventory planning directly reduces obsolescence and shrinkage by fundamentally changing *what* you stock and *how long* you hold it. Traditional min/max systems treat all inventory equally, leading to overstocking of slow-movers that eventually age out. Modern planning algorithms continuously recalculate optimal stock levels at the SKU-location level based on actual velocity, seasonal patterns, and shelf-life constraints. This prevents the root cause of obsolescence — buying too much of the wrong thing — rather than managing the symptoms. The system automatically adjusts safety stock downward for aging-prone items while maintaining service levels through more frequent, smaller replenishments.

The mechanism works through three levers: **velocity-based stocking** (eliminating tail SKU overstocks), **shelf-life awareness** (FEFO logic for perishables), and **rapid aging detection** (flagging slow-movers before they become unsaleable). McKinsey's Supply Chain 4.0 research documents comprehensive inventory reductions of **30-35%** in transformed operations, with obsolescence declining proportionally as companies hold less aging-vulnerable stock. IDC case studies show companies achieving **25% obsolescence reduction within 12 months** of implementing AI planning systems, primarily by eliminating speculative purchases and "just-in-case" buffer stocks that never turn.

The impact scales with inventory velocity and product lifecycle characteristics. A food distributor carrying 60-day inventory of products with 180-day shelf life faces fundamentally different risk than an industrial distributor with 90-day inventory of non-perishable fasteners. Companies typically see **10-15% reduction** in obsolescence cost at conservative implementation (basic velocity optimization), **15-25%** with moderate adoption (adding shelf-life logic and automated markdown triggers), and **25-40%** when fully mature (predictive aging, automated liquidation workflows). The prerequisite is clean master data — planning algorithms cannot distinguish between "didn't sell because overpriced" and "didn't sell because obsolete" without accurate product attributes, cost data, and transaction history.
